p.font: Tentative Return to School Set for May 1

span.b: April 1, 2020
Dear Parents/Guardians,

We hope this letter finds you and your family healthy and in good spirits. We want to take this opportunity to acknowledge you and thank you for helping the children navigate through their learning. We sent a survey, and teachers are reaching out to see what additional supports you may need during this time. We will be in contact with you once we know the needs of families to ensure success of the students.

On Tuesday, March 31st, the Governor extended the school closure through April 30th. We also began the transition from the designated “Act of God Days” to “Remote Learning Days” which will be considered instructional student attendance days. As we make this shift, expectations become more defined. In order for our school to count these as instructional days, instruction and student engagement needs to take place.
Grading Policies for Remote Learning Days

We will adopt the same grading policy as Hall High School during the Remote Learning Days. This grading policy takes into account recommendations from the state, accountability from students to do their work, and flexibility in instruction during these challenging times. During Remote Learning, new homework and any other new assessments will be entered into Teacherease as Complete, Incomplete, or Missing.
Complete means that a student has satisfied the criteria set by the teacher for the activity.
Incomplete means that a student has turned in the assignment but has not yet satisfied the criteria. Students may revise the assignment to receive a grade of Complete.

Missing means that NO ATTEMPT was made by the student to do the activity at all. Missing assignments are identified in Teacherease with a magnifying glass icon. Missing assignments may be made up to receive a grade of Complete.

Students who have questions or need additional help need to let the teacher know. Students who choose not to complete the necessary amount of work can anticipate being recommended for summer school or enrolling in an on-line credit recovery course through Keystone. We will work closely with each student and family to make sure the necessary resources are available to continue student learning.
At the end of the quarter

Any student in grades K-5 who has a final grade of an incomplete due to the amount of missing assignments will not receive credit for passing that class and may be assigned to a mandatory summer school or be retained.

Any student in grades 6-8 who has a final grade of an incomplete due to the amount of missing assignments will not receive credit for passing that class and may be required to enroll in a credit recovery class (at the parent’s expense) or be retained.
Attendance for Remote Learning

We were given guidance from the state to keep track of attendance, and the best way to do this is through TeacherEase. Students need to check in on TeacherEase anytime between 5:00 am and 10:00 pm each weekday. Even if the student is sick or out of town, attendance will be documented.
Assignments for Remote Learning
PK-2 graders will have assignments through packets and digital learning resources.
3-8 graders will proceed through a digital format.

K-2 grade students, elementary special education students, and students without internet access or electronic devices will be able to pick up packets for students on Tuesday, April 14th. We will be sending out detailed instructions next week for packet pick-up.
